Award.AwardTitle: PFI:AIR - TT: Lateral Field Excited Acoustic Wave Sensor for Monitoring Thin Film Properties in Solid State Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
This PFI: AIR Technology project focuses on translating research in lateral field excited (LFE) acoustic wave devices to fill the continuing need for improved methods of process monitoring and device metrology for manufacturing processes involving thin-film deposition. A wide range of electronic, microwave, and optical devices that use these thin films are commonplace in existing and future computers, automobiles, mobile communication systems (cell phones), etc. The capability of accurately monitoring thin film properties such as film thickness, mass, viscosity, electrical conductivity and permittivity during film deposition will improve the performance of consumer electronics that depend on these devices. The features associated with the LFE monitor will provide higher sensitivity when compared to the leading competing technology, the Quartz Crystal Microbalance (QCM) in this market space, and allow electrical conductivity and permittivity monitoring which are not possible with QCM.

The lateral field excited acoustic wave sensor under development is targeted for industrial factories and research laboratories which fabricate solid state electronic, microwave and optical devices that employ thin films critical to the device performance. In contrast to the commonly used QCM, the LFE device will allow the accurate and sensitive in situ monitoring of both mechanical (mass, film thicknesses and viscosity) and/or electrical (conductivity and permittivity) film properties. However, before this technology can be transitioned to a viable commercial product, two technology gaps have to be filled. First, the LFE device admittance response needs to be improved. Although the current LFE response is adequate for implementation in laboratory instrumentation, a larger change in admittance magnitude and phase is needed to realize a commercial sensor. The second gap involves the design and testing of an oscillator circuit in which the LFE device is a feedback element. In this configuration, the change in oscillator frequency becomes a direct measure of the change in film mechanical and/or electrical properties.

University of Maine (UM) faculty in Electrical Engineering and Business Entrepreneurship and Fil-Tech engineers will advise undergraduates and graduate MS and PhD students in acoustic wave technology and/or business entrepreneurship necessary to realize a laboratory prototype that can be transitioned into a commercial product. In order to prepare the LFE sensor for technology transfer and commercialization, the UM Department of Industrial Cooperation will work with Fil-Tech, Inc. to develop intellectual property licensing.

The project engages Fil-Tech Inc. to provide customized quartz samples and guidance critical in transitioning this technology to a viable commercial product.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction

The purpose of this project was to improve the performance of lateral-field excited (LFE) bulk acoustic wave (BAW) sensing devices, to transition them to industry; demonstrate for the first-time electronic interfaces for the LFE sensors, which would allow them to be integrated into commercial products; and to train graduate and undergraduate students in both technical research and commercialization.

LFE bulk acoustic wave devices are related to industry-standard quartz BAW devices which are used in time-keeping (for example in watches and computer) and sensor applications. The standard quartz crystal microbalance (QCM), like its time-keeping cousins, has its metal electrodes covering both its top and bottom surfaces (figures 1 and 2). This limits their sensing applications to mechanical properties only, as the electrical properties of the neighboring medium/material are masked by the top electrode. In contrast, the LFE device has both its electrodes on the same (back) side, leaving the sensor surface base (figures 1 and 2). The LFE is thus able to sense electrical properties as well, with more potential sensing applications.

Major Findings:

Previous work on the LFE sensor demonstrated its applications to various fields. However, the original sensor's impedance response has a very narrow frequency bandwidth, making it difficult to work with commercial electronic interface circuits (figure 3). The impedance response of the LFE was improved by optimizing the curvature of the crystal; electrode size, shape and distance; and adding thin layers of materials on the sensing surface to better confine the acoustic energy. These modifications result in a 40 decibel, i.e. 10,000 fold, improvement in the impedance response of the LFE sensor in air, along with a 10 fold increase in the frequency bandwidth from under 100 Hz to more than 1 kHz (figure 4).

A collaboration with researchers at Thayer School of Engineering, Dartmouth University, was established to explore the application of LFE sensors to cancer biomarker detection. Early research concentrated on attaching the biomarker selective films with peptic nucleic acid (PNA) on to the surface of the bare quartz, a process that previously required a metal surface. This was followed by demonstration of LFE sensor response to pancreatic cancer mimics once the sensor surface was functionalized. The LFE sensor?s ability to detect electrical changes is predicted to improve the sensitivity and limit-of-detection of cancer screening tests.

The first successful miniaturized electrical interface for the original LFE device was demonstrate in the form of a phase-shift tracking Phase-Mass System (figure 1, bottom row). This allows for a portable, hand-held instrument to be built using the original LFE sensor. After the LFE sensor response was improve, stable oscillation was demonstrated for the first time with standard QCM oscillator configurations. This in turn would allow the LFE sensor to be a drop-in replacement for the standard QCM sensor.

Commercialization:

The thin-film deposition industry was selected as the initial target for commercializing the LFE sensor. Companies in that use thin-film deposition include those manufacturing parts for optical equipment (e.g. lenses, prisms), semiconductors (microprocessors, memory chips), and microelectro-mechanical systems (MEMS, sensors, micromachines).  The LFE sensor would allow these companies to the monitor electrical properties of these films during deposition. This would in turn allow the companies to improve the quality control of existing products and develop new products by tailoring the electrical properties of their thin films.

The commercialization effort included customer discovery interviews with representatives from the targeted industries. Analysis of these interviews showed the problems the industries have related to measurement error, repeatability and accuracy of measurements. The increased sensitivity of the LFE device can help with the last two. Contact was established with Fil-Tech LLC, a manufacturer of quartz crystals and thin-film deposition monitoring equipment.

Broader Impact on Society:

The LFE sensor has several potential ways to improve society in general. The LFE sensor used in thin film deposition equipment can allow semiconductor manufacturers to develop novel products, ranging from better performing microprocessors for computers and cell phones to electronic devices for more efficiently converting solar energy to electricity. The LFE sensor?s ability to detect electrical changes is predicted to improve the sensitivity and limit-of-detection of cancer screening tests. Early detection of cancers, such as pancreatic cancer, will potentially save thousands of lives annually.

In human resource development, two graduate students and five undergraduate students were trained in basic research and product development using state-of-the-art equipment and techniques. Two graduate students were also trained in commercialization, conducting customer discovery interviews and interacting with business managers and engineers working in industry.
